page.title: 05FARMING IN EDGEFIELD & AREA
page.content: Agriculture is the prime concern of the area. The main crops are cereals, root crops including potatoes and sugar beet, and grassland for grazing of both cattle and sheep.One farm concentrates on chickens and another on pigs. Edgefield Hall has a trout farm. Most of the farms are owner- occupied, but some belong to the Stody estates. (Stody is about 2 miles west of our area.) There is also managed woodland: some of the plantations are of conifers with an edging of deciduous trees, so that visually they appear in the landscape as an older style of planting. There is still a Little Wood & once there was Great Wood which belonged to Binham Priory. The felling of Great Wood during the Napoleonic wars affected the population of Edgefield as it provided employment.
